g.text: Zhan et al. Mg Ion Solid Electrolyte
Therefore, next generation advanced rechargeable batteries,
such as multivalent metal (Mg, Ca, Al etc.) batteries, have
aroused much interest due to high energy density in theory
Aurbach et al., 2000, 2007; Yoo et al., 2013; Wang et al.,
). Among them, rechargeable Mg batteries are considered
as the most promising battery technology because of the highest
theoretical volumetric energy density of Mg anode (3,866 mAh
), surpassing that of Li anode (2,066 mAh cm
with water, the reaction between Mg and water is much more
stable because of the passive Mg hydroxide/oxide ﬁlm formed
on the surface. In addition, there is no dendrite formed for
Mg anode during the reversible plating/stripping process. These
advantages endow Mg anode high safety compared to Li anode
). In addition, Mg is more abundant relative
Several key challenges, however, should be overcome before
the Mg battery technology comes true (
Saha et al., 2014; Bucur et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2020
instance, due to the electrochemical reduction, a passivation
layer is formed on Mg anode surface once Mg is on contact
with conventional carbonate-based electrolyte solvents used in
). While conducting for Li ion in
LIBs, solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is insulating for Mg ion
and thus prevents the conventional electrolyte solvents to be
therefore developed for Mg batteries and most of them are
based on Grignard reagents dissolved in ethereal solvents or
). Nevertheless, concerns on safety and stability still
remain for the high vapor pressure and the high ﬂammability
of ether-based organic solvents. Furthermore, the presence
anions in Grignard reagents results in the high
corrosion and the electrolytes also have narrow electrochemical
state electrolyte employed by all-solid-state Mg batteries is
a safe alternative in terms of heat and mechanical shock
Ikeda et al., 1987; Imanaka et al., 1999; Janek
development of solid-state Mg ion conductor with suﬃcient
conductivity is a key challenge at ambient temperature because
of the sluggish mobility resulted by the high charge density
Janek and Zeier, 2016; Famprikis et al., 2019
Many eﬀorts are thus devoted to improve the mobility of Mg
ion within the solid conductor and the target is 10
at ambient temperature, which is comparable with
those of solid electrolytes used in lithium or sodium batteries
In this mini review, we will present a comprehensive
development of solid Mg ion conductors, including phosphates,
chalcogenides. It highlights the performance and the limitation
of each material and also discusses the conduction mechanism
on the basis of the crystal structure and the strategy to improve
The study on solid-state ionic conductors have aroused much
interest due to the merits of high stability and good safety. It is
well-accepted that the migration of ion species is quite diﬃcult in
a solid, highly aﬀected by the valence states of the ion species.
Therefore, while there are many kinds of monovalent ionic
conductors with high conductivity, few choices are available for
known for permitting the smooth migration of Na ion species
due to the well-ordered three-dimensional network structure,
and therefore it is highly interested to develop NASICON-type
Lee et al., 2019; Shao et al., 2019
The earliest report on NASICON-type Mg
came from Ikeda in 1987, who studied the system of Mg-
in various molar ratios as Mg ion conductor using
The Tubandt’s method and the electron probe microanalysis
were used to conﬁrm the charge carrier to be Mg ions.
According to X-ray diﬀraction (XRD) measurements, the author
simply claimed that the crystal structure of MZP similar to
, resulted in the best conductivity relative to analogs
with other ratios, while no further evidence was provided in
Imanaka and Adachi continued the exploration on
varied the starting materials of MZP to be non-stoichiometric
ratios so as to produce the secondary phase of Zr
content in the composite, the Mg ion conductivity
increased to a maximum value of 6.92
conductivity of the composite because of the insulating property
. The presence of secondary phase was believed to
enhance the relative density and thus the ionic conductivity by
In 2001, Imanaka used the substitution strategy to improve the
ionic conductivity of MZP by partially replacing Zr
). The substitution was used to statistically
distribute mobile Mg ions to make a smooth Mg ion diﬀusion
but it also reduced the number of migrating Mg
in the solid solution electrolyte. Thus, the optimumconductivity
C, demonstrating little enhancement compared to
Later in 2016, Imanaka and Tamura claimed that most of
the attempts to obtain the NASICON-type structure of Mg
ion conductor were unsuccessful, because of the small ionic
